Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Profiling Dynamic Changes in Animal Circadian Clock Protein Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
The objective of this EAGER project is to profile the dynamic interactions between circadian oscillator protein compleesx and other cellular machineries by using mass spectrometry-based proteomics and Drosophila melanogaster as a model. This project is to develop foundational data to probe the dynamic rewiring of the circadian interactome necessary for biological timekeeping. Looking ahead, results from this project will lay the foundation for (i) functional characterization of new clock components, and (ii) comparative protein network analysis of the circadian interactomes in multiple species with distinct clock designs. This comparison coupled with rigorous mathematical approaches will highlight network rewiring and differential interactions that can reflect inherent flexibility and adaptability of the clock network.

Broader Impacts:
Circadian biology is a fascinating topic that people of all ages and backgrounds can relate to, as circadian clocks regulate physiological processes that are of interest to many, and therefore represents a perfect platform for science education. The PI and her colleagues developed a multi-faceted plan to use insect circadian rhythms to educate and inspire future generations of scientists of all ages and engage the general public. This project will also provide cross-disciplinary training and career development opportunities for graduate students, undergraduates, and high school teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The circadian clock is an endogenous timing system that exists in all kingdoms of life, from bacteria to animals. It enables the integration of environmental signals and metabolic status to ensure that organisms perform necessary tasks at biologically advantageous times of day. Although extensive work has been performed to identify a number of key conserved proteins in animals that make up the core timekeeping oscillator in the circadian timing system, the mechanisms by which the oscillator protein module receives input time cues and subsequently transduce this timing information to output physiological pathways to generate the rhythms of life are not well understood. The overall goal of this project is to gain insight into these important mechanisms that enable organisms to properly time biological activities. As protein-protein interactions are important in the transduction of circadian timing information within an organism, protein network analysis centering on the oscillator protein module in the model organism Drosophila melanogaster was conducted using mass spectrometry-based proteomics over a circadian timeframe to understand the complex protein network rewiring that is essential for biological timekeeping. Proteomic data analysis pipeline was developed to analyze the network connections between the oscillator and cellular protein complexes. This project uncovered previously unknown protein interactions and shed light on the dynamic protein network rewiring necessary for timekeeping.

Broader Impact:

This project provided training opportunities and career development for graduate students, undergraduates, as well as high school students from K-12 levels. Exhibits showcasing insect circadian rhythms were organized at the Bohart Museum of Entomology (BME) at UC Davis. Laboratory workshop catering underserved high school student population was conducted to provide hands on laboratory experience to promote learning and increase interests in STEM education. Video training tools were developed as resources for laboratory workshops and for training students involved in this project.

Modified by: Joanna C Chiu
